Describing your skills and passions
Literature
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Hi Jane. I've just finished my book. Do you have something I could borrow?
Yes, I've got loads of books. What kind of thing do you want? What book did you just finish?
The one I read was actually [k]non-fiction[/k], a diary of a traveller many years ago. But I like lots of things really.
Well, I have an [k]autobiography[/k] by another traveller. He's Spanish but grew up in Africa in the 50s.
That sounds perfect. I really like books that give me a sense of adventure and help me learn about a particular place or time.
Actually, this one is also good because it contains lots of traditional African stories and [k]poetry[/k] that the [k]author[/k] heard or read as he grew up.
That sounds really interesting. Thanks for letting me borrow it. What are you reading at the moment?
I've just started a [k]novel[/k] by a Russian author. It [k]is set in[/k] the early 80s and the [k]main character[/k] is a very intelligent young woman. It's really good.
Robert
Jane
Select the correct option.
Select the words in the correct order.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Describe the plot of your favourite novel or film.
In my favourite novel the main character is a man who wakes up one day and discovers that he is now an insect! The author is Franz Kafka and the book is called Metamorphosis.
Future continuous
The sentence talks about the future.
I'm working at the moment.
True or false?
I'll be relaxing by the pool this time tomorrow.
We won't be using the meeting room then.
We use the Future Continuous tense to talk about actions that will (or won't) be happening at a specific time in the future. We often use time expressions in the future:
I'll be relaxing by the pool this time next week. We won't be using the meeting room at 4 o'clock tomorrow.
The sentence talks about an action that will be in progress at a time in the future.
At 5 o'clock I'll be talking to the new manager.
We will leave the house at 7 o'clock.
We'll be driving all through the night.
The Future Continuous tense is used to talk about actions in progress at a point in the future:
At 5 o'clock I'll be talking to the new manager.
The Future Continuous tense is also used to talk about future arrangements and plans that will be happening at a time in the future:
We'll be driving all through the night.
[k]Dave[/k] [k]will[/k] [k]be[/k] [k]arriving soon.[/k]
[k]We'll[/k] [k]be[/k] [k]getting on the train[/k] [k]at 7 o'clock tomorrow.[/k]
[k]My parents[/k] [k]will[/k] [k]be[/k] [k]staying with us[/k] [k]next weekend.[/k]
To make the Future Continuous tense we use will + be + -ing form of the verb. 'Will' is often contracted when used with pronouns:
I'll be working late tonight. He'll be having a party on the 23rd.
[k]I[/k] [k]won't[/k] [k]be[/k] [k]sleeping then.[/k]
[k]What[/k] [k]will[/k] [k]you[/k] [k]be[/k] [k]working on[/k] [k]tomorrow morning?[/k]
[k]We[/k] [k]won't[/k] [k]be[/k] [k]using the meeting room[/k] [k]until 3 o'clock.[/k]
To make negative sentences in the Future Continuous Tense we use will + not, this is usually contracted to won't.
I won't be using the computer tonight.
To make questions we put the subject between 'will' and 'be'.
Will you be using the computer tonight?
This time next week I'll [k]be sitting[/k] on a beach in Spain.
sit

[k]We'll be staying|We will be staying[/k] in a hotel tomorrow night.

Future Continuous tense - I not sleep
[k]I won't be sleeping|I will not be sleeping[/k]; come over whenever you want.
Future Continuous tense - you do
What [k]will you be doing[/k] at midnight?

Where [k]will you be eating[/k]? I'll come and find you.
Future Continuous tense - they arrive
[k]They will be arriving|They'll be arriving[/k] soon. Are we ready?
Grammar: Third conditional
The sentence talks about a hypothetical past.
If they'd played better, they would have won the match.
I would have gone to university if I'd had more money.
I didn't enjoy the play because it was really boring.
If we want to talk about an unreal or hypothetical situation in the past and the imagined result of this situation, we can use the Third Conditional.
If they'd played better, they would have won the match.
The sentence expresses regret.
If I had worked harder, I would have got a promotion.
If I hadn't taken a taxi, I would have got very wet.
We would have got married if I hadn't been so stupid.
We often (but not always) use the Third Conditional to express some regret about a past situation or behaviour and the imagined result if things had been different.
If I had worked harder, I would have got a promotion.
The sentence expresses possibility or ability in the past.
We could have been famous if we'd practiced more.
She would have won the race if she hadn't fallen over.
I might have been an actor if I'd grown up in Hollywood.
We can use could have and might have to express possibility and ability related to unreal situations in the past.

I could have been... (ability)
I might have been... (possibility)
[k]If we[/k] [k]had gone to the party,[/k] [k]we would[/k] [k]have had fun.[/k]
[k]She would have worked[/k] [k]harder[/k] [k]if her boss had been[/k] [k]more supportive.[/k]
[k]If we[/k] [k]had known[/k] [k]the rules,[/k] [k]we would[/k] [k]have parked[/k] [k]in a different place.[/k]
We form the Third Conditional with if + Past Perfect tense, Would have + Past Participle.
If I'd worked harder, I would have passed the exam.
The main clause and the conditional clause can be either way around in the sentence.

If I'd seen him, I would have said hello.
I would have said hello if I'd seen him.
'Would' can be replaced by 'could' or 'might' to express ability or possibility.
I might have got the job if I had arrived on time for the interview.
[k]If I[/k] [k]had[/k] [k]seen him,[/k] [k]I[/k] [k]wouldn't[/k] [k]have said[/k] [k]hello.[/k]
[k]If we[/k] [k]hadn't[/k] [k]taken an umbrella,[/k] [k]we[/k] [k]would[/k] [k]have got[/k] [k]very wet.[/k]
[k]What[/k] [k]would you[/k] [k]have done[/k] [k]if[/k] [k]they[/k] [k]hadn't given you[/k] [k]the job?[/k]

We can make negative conditionals by adding 'not' to either or both of the clauses. This is often contracted:
had + not = hadn't
would + not = wouldn't
I wouldn't have got wet if I hadn't forgoten my umbrella.
If I [k]had[/k] passed the ball, we [k]would have[/k] scored a goal.
have
will have
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
I wouldn't have [k]been[/k] ill if I [k]hadn't eaten[/k] that out-of-date food.
be
didn't eat
What [k]would you[/k] have done if [k]you had[/k] been in my position?
you would
Which cities would you [k]have visited[/k] [k]if[/k] you'd had more time?
visit
when
Third Conditional - be
There [k]would have been|would've been[/k] some food left if Barry hadn't eaten it all.
Third Conditional - win
We could have been millionaires if we [k]had won[/k] the lottery.
Third Conditional - may get
She [k]might have got|might've got[/k] the job if she'd written a better cover letter.
